Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Hime-firefly (Luciola parvula) conservation and local knowledge in central Japan: community-based environmental research in the diffusion of innovation perspective

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, I researched the activities of citizen-led conservation groups in Japan that work with a species of firefly called the “hime-firefly.” The overall goal of this research was to compare how location, specifically urban vs. rural, can influence conservation group activities both in Japan and in a more general sense.

There are three main reasons why I specifically chose this topic. First, although there is some knowledge about conservation groups in the United States and other countries, there is little research available about such groups in Japan and Asian in general. Second, with in the studies done on conservation group activities, subject of “location” has yet to be explored in detail. Third, in Japan, while research on fireflies themselves is not uncommon, research on the groups that work to protect them is severely lacking. Study on this subject can be useful for conservation policy, improving the effectiveness of conservation activities by citizen-led groups, as well as for other researchers.

My project took the form of six short case studies on urban and rural hime-firefly groups in central Japan. I visited various places in Japan in order to meet with and interview members of these groups. I asked questions about a variety of topics including group goals, activities, and accomplishments; the kinds of resources they use, difficulties groups may have and things they thought were important for future success. I interviewed three urban groups (one in Suita City and two in Nagoya), two rural groups (Tanba and Wadayama in Hyogo Pref.) and suburban one group in Gotemba City. Furthermore, I was able to visit the actual hime-firefly habitats in each area, collected data in the form of documents and attended two hime-firefly viewing/appreciation events. I also shared information about my project and preliminary results at the COP10 Hime-Firefly Summit in Nagoya (August 2011).  

In the end, being able to interview hime-firefly groups operating in a variety of settings allowed me to get a good general picture of what groups are trying to accomplish and how; what problems groups face; what resources are available them; recommendations they have for other groups, and so on.  Although all groups get together for the sake of hime-fireflies, goals and activities varied a great deal and did not center solely on firefly conservation/protection. For instance, some groups wanted to strengthening connections between people, while others used fireflies as a way to attract tourism or as a way to build appreciation for the local area. 

Perhaps some of the most important information gained from my research project was information about how groups could improve their operations and what could help improve the effectiveness of firefly conservation. Based on interviews, there is a pressing need to learn more about habitat management for hime-fireflies, which may be accomplished more effectively if researchers and groups were able to collaborative on more activities. Related to this, groups also expressed a desire to increase communication of information both between groups and with researchers; however, it is difficult to exchange information well due to the lack of a central network. If it were possible to create this sort of network for information exchange, data sharing and communication between people involved, it would have great potential to help both researchers and firefly groups.

As for how location influences group activities, at this point it is difficult to make any specific conclusions about the differences between urban and rural groups. There was much more variety among hime-firefly groups than expected and therefore more interviews or surveys will need to be done to collect additional data.
